Cherry blossoms will be at peak March 28-31, Park Service says The National Park Service predicted Thursday that D.C.’s iconic cherry trees will reach peak bloom from March 28 to March 31. Peak bloom is declared by the agency when 70 percent of the blossoms around the Tidal Basin — the reservoir on the National Mall — have opened. Organizers expect 1.5 million people to visit the flowering trees during this year’s National Cherry Blossom Festival. The festival, which commemorates the 3,000 cherry trees Japan gifted to the United States as a symbol of friendship in 1912, will run from March 20 through April 13. The event — featuring an opening ceremony of Japanese performers, a parade along Constitution Avenue, live music at the Tidal Basin and a kite festival on the Washington Monument grounds — kicks off spring. “It’s really one of the traditions of the nation’s capital,” said Mike Litterst, a spokesperson for the Park Service. “It’s that sign that spring is finally here. It’s sort of that one unifying thing that occurs in D.C. It’s not blue, it’s not red; for the few weeks that the trees are out, everybody is all about the pink.” This year marks the first cherry blossom season when construction will be underway to rehabilitate the crumbling sea walls around the Tidal Basin and West Potomac Park. The three-year renovation is part of a nearly $500 million project to improve infrastructure on the National Mall before the 250th anniversary of American independence in 2026. Litterst said visitors should expect construction between the Jefferson and Franklin D. Roosevelt memorials, typically prime real estate for cherry blossom viewing. “Folks will find fencing, they’ll find screening in places, but all of the walkways are open, the roads are open and, most significantly, there will still be plenty of cherry trees in bloom,” Litterst said. Last year, the Park Service removed 158 cherry trees for the project — including the much-loved Stumpy — but Litterst said more than 2,500 trees remain around the Tidal Basin, with roughly 1,000 more on the Washington Monument grounds and in East Potomac Park. The Washington Post’s Capital Weather Gang independently estimates peak bloom and predicted this year that the blossoms will reach peak bloom between March 23 and 27, about five days earlier than normal. According to the Capital Weather Gang, climate change has spurred D.C.’s iconic trees to flower earlier over time. The blossom’s average peak has advanced about a week over the past century, from April 4 to March 29, with last year’s March 17 peak bloom tying for the second-earliest on record. March 15, 1990, was the earliest record peak bloom. City leaders, including D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser, and National Cherry Blossom Festival organizers gathered at an annual news conference Thursday at the Waldorf Astoria in downtown D.C. to announce the peak bloom prediction. Diana Mayhew, president of the National Cherry Blossom Festival, credited the event for making D.C. “the springtime destination,” in an interview ahead of the event. Last year, she said 1.6 million people — 46 percent from the D.C. area and 54 percent tourists — flocked to the nation’s capital to witness the beauty of the blossoms. The festival generated $202 million in visitor spending in D.C. last year, Mayhew said. City leaders have hoped in recent years that the cherry blossoms could be a catalyst for tourism and reinvigorating the city’s struggling downtown since the pandemic. But Mayhew, who has organized the festival for 25 years, added that it’s important to her that the celebration is not only for tourists. To “roll out the pink carpet for everyone,” she said, festival organizers have launched community outreach programs and partnerships in all eight D.C. wards. Many of the initiatives focus on youths, including a program that sends local artists to lead workshops at D.C. schools and the “Kites in the Classroom” program, which encourages elementary-schoolers to design, build and fly their own kites as an extension of the Blossom Kite Festival. On Thursday, Mayhew also said the festival would include a new event to “to keep Stumpy’s spirit alive.” The first Stumpy’s Petals and Paddles boat race will take place on March 20 at the Tidal Basin. “Spring is such a joyous time here in D.C.” Mayhew said.
